children: A 31-year old man is evaluated for increased skin fragility involving the face, scalp, and dorsal hands, as
. The patient has risk factors for hepatitis C virus infection.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT), a hereditary or acquired blistering disease caused by excess circulating porphyrins. Patients present with vesicles, bullae, and skin fragility on sun-exposed skin, most commonly on the face, dorsal hands (as seen in this patient), and scalp; photosensitivity is the hallmark of the disease. Other features include hyperpigmentation, milia (tiny inclusion cysts), hypertrichosis, and alopecia. Up to 50% of patients with sporadic PCT have hepatitis C virus infection.
